description:
You are invited to a reception in support of
Gretchen Driskell (MI-07) and Suzanna Shkreli (MI-08)

Tuesday, August 23rd, 2016 12:30pm - 2:00 pm

At Arbor Brewing Company
114 E. Washington St. 
Ann Arbor, MI 48104

Suggested Contribution Levels:
$50 Friend
$100 Guest
$250 Supporter
$500 Sponsor
$1,000 Champion

Join us for refreshments, conversation, and an update from the campaign trail with Congresswoman Debbie Dingell, Congresswoman Cheri Bustos, and Congresswoman Lois Frankel.

RSVP to Hattie McKinney at 734-707-7150 or gretchen@votegretchen.com or Arianna Kendall at 202-688.8372 or arianna@suzannaforcongress.com or Philip Stein at 202-741-1363 or Stein@dccc.org
OR online at https://secure.actblue.com/contribute/page/driskellshkreli2016

Donors may choose how much and to whom to contribute.
Checks will be collected, treated, and reported as conduit contributions by the DCCC.

Please make checks payable to each campaign. Committee Names are also listed in the disclaimer box.
Please mail your check along with this form to: DCCC c/o Philip Stein
430 South Capitol Street SE, 2nd Floor Washington, DC 20003
name: Women LEAD Luncheon with Rep Dingell, Rep Bustos, and Rep Frankel

description:
Please join us for a special, invitation-only "Dinner With Circus Sensation David Dimitri", a benefit for the Ann Arbor Summer Festival. 

Join festival director Amy Nesbitt and select festival donors for a dinner supporting the week-long residency of world-renowned circus performer and high-wire walker David Dimitri.

David will be performing his magical "One Man Circus" August 24th - 28th in Burns Park. This is a unique opportunity to get to know David personally, hear wonderful stories of his 20+ years of performances worldwide and enjoy charming anecdotes of a globally respected artist before Opening Night.

Tickets are Available Now:
$100  Dinner Only
$150  Dinner + 1 Ticket to Opening Night performance of One Man Circus on 8/24

Festivities will kick off in the Private Room at Mezzevino on Liberty and 4th Street.

6:15 pm - Join us for socializing over delicious appetizers such as the Mediterranean hummus platter with crisp vegetables and marinated olives, and creative flatbreads. Enjoy a glass of wine, beer, soda, iced tea, or coffee.

6:45 pm - Dinner will include Mezzevino's famed Greek Salad, Braised Beef Tips, and Vegetarian Pasta Primavera.

Many thanks to Ellie Serras and the staff at Mezzevino for their generous assistance with this event. Ticket buyers will receive an acknowledgement letter from the festival detailing the charitable portion of their purchase for tax purposes.

We look forward to seeing you!

Heather Steenrod
Donor and Corporate Partnerships Manager
Ann Arbor Summer Festival
Steenrod@a2sf.org
name: Dinner With Circus Sensation David Dimitri

description:
Drink and Draw is back just in time for the dog days of summer! This one is for all of you bar-napkin savants, you web-comic-ers, you dabblers, dawdlers and you doodlers alike. An event to unite Ann Arbor artists of all calibers, for drinking, drawing and over-all merriment (and not necessarily in that order). We invite you to join us on August 23rd at Bill's Beer Garden for a night of great company, conversation and collaboration.

Spots are limited so get in touch with us today! To reserve your space, message us on Facebook, shoot us an email, or drop us a line!
name: Drink & Draw

description:
Arbor Brewing Company presents...
ACOUSTIC TUESDAYS!
Every Tuesday at 7pm, we’ll be featuring live acoustic sets from the area’s most talented artists.

Zak Shaffer has an “infectious live performance that can’t be beat”! He is an incredibly talented
rising star who’s blending of rock, blues, pop, bluegrass & country creates catchy & original sounds on
the guitar. He is a soulful vocalist who can growl better than any rocker & can croon with the best in
country music.
http://zakshaffer.com/

New a cover
Always a good time
name: Acoustic Tuesdays: Zak Shaffer

description:
August 9–October 30, 2016
Corridor Gallery

Artist and poet Ann Holmes first encountered Japanese folk ceramics while living in Tokyo in the late 1960s. Fascinated by the simple aesthetic, the craftsmanship, and the makers’ unassuming personalities and ways of life, Holmes visited many kiln towns to photograph and interview the artists and collect ceramic wares of various shapes and techniques. She donated a significant portion of her collection to UMMA in 2013.

Richly introduced in this presentation are works by ceramic artists emerging in the late 1960s and the early 1970s in the town of Mashiko, two hours north of Tokyo by train. Mashiko became an international mecca of folk ceramics after Hamada Shōji (1894–1978), a major figure of Japan’s Folk Craft (Mingei) Movement, set up his studio there in 1930. Hamada’s idea of ceramic making for a new age, which combined the aesthetic of folk ceramics and the modern concept of the studio artist, attracted many younger artists of unconventional backgrounds, including women.
name: In Focus: Modern Japanese Folk Ceramics

description:
Our August Artists’ Meet & Greet topic is “Life Between the Right and Left Brain”, involving an extensive talk by electrical engineer, lawyer, writer and artist John Posa about his artistic influences, productivity, and legal (primarily copyright) issues. Join us for this free event, connect with other artists, and the Art Center staff.

Speaker: John Posa (awarded 3rd place for his piece “Untitled”, in our current exhibition Real American)

Our monthly Artists' Meet & Greets held at the 117 Gallery are a perfect opportunity to connect with the Art Center, network with other artists, and attend artist talks by guest speakers.

Learn more about our Artist Meet & Greet Events:
http://www.annarborartcenter.org/artists-meet-greet/
name: Life Between the Right and Left Brain

description:
Enter the magical world of David Dimitri. Lauded “Lord of the Wire” by The New York Times, this world famous high-wire dancer and veteran of Cirque du Soleil and Big Apple Circus epitomizes innovation as he alone performs an entire circus. Creating what he calls “a unique magic” in the intimate setting of a tent in Burns Park, his L’homme Cirque balances dramatic feats like high-wire flips and a human cannon launch with humor, poetry, and serenades on the accordion. It’s as gripping as it is charming—and with a grand flourish, be awestruck as he exits the tent on his high wire, crossing above at 150 feet “and into the sky.”

Please note: Tickets should be purchased in advance, if any tickets remain, they will be sold at the tent 30 minutes prior the show. The tent is wheelchair accessible with advance notice and tent capacity is limited. For everyone's comfort and safety, please note that the tent has a cooling feature that is used if it is a particularly hot day. Performance parking is available at the Burns Park Elementary lot for a $5 donation to the PTO.

$20 Kids & $30 Adult - General Admission
Parking at the Burns Park Elementary School

Sponsored by: Toyota USA
Presented in part with support from: National Endowment for the Arts
This performance is generously underwritten by Ellie Serras.
Media Partner: Michigan Radio 91.7

August 24 @ 6:30 pm, Burns Park 
August 25 @ 6:30 pm, Burns Park
August 26 @ 6:30 pm, Burns Park 
August 27 @ 6:30 pm, Burns Park 
August 28 @ 6:30 pm, Burns Park

Watch the videos:
The Show: https://youtu.be/TB0Oyl1gSNk

Highwire Stunts: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rqCzjvM3_Sc

On a Treadmill: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oxrqksjrMf0
name: One-Man Circus (L’homme Cirque)

description:
Join the Potawatomi Mountain Biking Association at Mt Brighton on Wednesday, August 24th as we present a special screening of ”Ride the Divide”, a feature about the world’s toughest mountain bike race. Movie tickets are $10 and all proceeds benefit the ongoing development of the DTE Energy Foundation Trail in Chelsea, Michigan.
  
At 7:00pm, southeast Michigan’s own Jesse Ramsey will discuss his recent experience in the Tour Divide. Jesse began the trek across the continental divide on June 10th and rode over 2700 miles from Banff, Alberta, Canada to the Mexican border finishing at Antelope Wells, NM. It took him 23 days and 13 hours to complete the 2016 Tour Divide. Jesse is a ”super rad and handsome dude, that likes free pizza”, and his mental and physical strength and perseverance is truly remarkable.
  
The movie, ”Ride the Divide”, will begin after Jesse’s presentation, and he will return after the movie for a brief Q&A session.
name: Ride the Divide Movie Screening
